Recent developments, industrialization, and modernization lead to production of more and more pollutants (such as CO2: ∼ 417.06 ppm) and such rapid growth of CO2 level results in global warming and the greenhouse effect. So, it is essential to conduct research on converting CO2 into fuels using carbon-neutral energy. Recent research on molecular catalysts has improved the rates of converting CO2 to formate. However, these catalysts require extremely high temperatures and pressures and are made of expensive metals like iridium, ruthenium, and rhodium. Herein, DFT-based computational studies have been performed on the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 by different Ni(II) complexes in ambient conditions. Using state-of-the-art calculations, we demonstrate how the geometry and spin states of Ni(II) complexes containing different types of ligands affect their catalytic role in CO2 hydrogenation. It has been reported that hydride transfer is the most crucial step for such kind of hydrogenation reaction. We start with previously synthesised Ni-bis(diphosphine) complexes of type NiP4 and by extrapolating the concept, we propose a novel kind of Ni-PNP complex with a significantly lower hydride transfer barrier. We also calculate the hydricities of the nickel hydride complexes in order to correlate these thermodynamic parameters with the kinetic barrier of hydride transfer. CO2 emissions avoidance plans and direct CO2 utilization are the two primary strategies for reducing CO2 emissions in chemistry. In the initial case, CO2 emissions are decreased by staying away from carbon-intensive substrates and processes. The second method uses waste CO2 directly as a reagent to produce high value-added products such as formic acid, CO, methane, methanol, C2 products and other organic compounds. The last ten years have seen a lot of interest in polyhydroxyurethanes (PHUs), which are possible substitutes for conventional phosgene-based polyurethanes (PUs). Utilizing CO2 and upcycling renewable sources to create sustainable PHUs through the production of CO2-based five-membered cyclic carbonates (5CCs) from biobased epoxides is an effective strategy. However, catalytic conversion of CO2 into useful chemicals and fuels can address both problems, and as a result, it has gained more global interest [1,2,3]. Collecting CO2 and converting it into formic acid/formate or methanol has become a promising route for mitigating the greenhouse impact and also fulfil the global energy demands. This process can be done using thermal or photochemical techniques [4]. For the conversation of CO2 to the desired valuable products, the most challenging task for this process is overcoming the high activation energy barrier of the stable carbon dioxide molecule to form the products. So, different suitable catalysts are used to accelerate the reaction. To activate stable CO2, a sufficiently strong electron donating metal centre is required which can undergo significant amount of electrons transfer to the antibonding π* orbitals of the desired molecule [5,6]. In the previous few decades, a variety of late transition metal-based compounds, metal nanoparticles (NPs) supported on metal oxides and transition metal carbides (TMC), have been used as catalysts for the reduction of CO2 in both homogeneous and heterogeneous conditions [7,8]. Different NPs supported on metal oxides such as NiO/CeO2, Cu/Al2O3, Cu-Ni/γAl2O3, Fe-Mo/γAl2O3, etc. and TMC such as TiC and MoC have been used for conversion of CO2 to CO, MeOH and CH4. In the last several years, TMCs have developed into a family of materials that play an increasing role in heterogeneous catalysis. The use of single-atom catalysts (SACs) to connect heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts has enormous potential [9,10,11,12]. Although some late transition metal have shown some success in conversion rates, but they are far from commercialization because of their high costs. Because of this, the only way to accomplish the goal is by utilizing early transition metal catalysts which are inexpensive in nature. Direct reduction of CO2 can lead to CO or can be hydrogenated into formic acid/formate. The latter one is more advantageous because of the nontoxicity, ease of transportation of the products and most importantly, formate/formic acid can be directly utilized into fuel cells. In the previous several decades, the hydrogenation of CO2 has been catalysed by numerous transition-metal complexes with high catalytic efficiency, but most of catalyst complexes are late transition metals like ruthenium, iridium, and rhodium, which are obviously expensive, toxic and scarcity in nature [13]. Because of some demerits of late transition metal system, researchers recently give special attention for the first-row transition-metal based catalysts system for the hydrogenation of CO2 due to its lower cost, more available in nature and its environmental friendliness [14,15,16,17]. Under mild conditions, nickel and copper complexes are effective at catalyzing and transforming CO2. In the same way iron, manganese, cobalt, and titanium-based catalysts can also be used [18]. Besides the activity of the metal, solvent plays a vital role in the catalytic reaction. Acrylonitrile, THF, and other aprotic organic solvents are among the most effective hydrogenating solvents that have been reported [19]. Therefore, using protic solvent in the catalytic process especially in water medium, is of prime interest area among the researcher. pH of the reaction medium plays an important role. Noteworthy, the catalytic activity of the metal complexes is highly impacted by the pH of the reaction medium. This is true because, during the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2, the pH of the medium has a significant impact on both the hydride transfer from metal hydride to CO2 and the regeneration of the metal hydride. Thus, to get the maximum longevity and activity out of the catalyst, these two factors must be balanced. As a result, it is currently challenging to design complexes based on earth abundant transition metals that can hydrogenate CO2 in water at ambient conditions. Along with electrocatalysis, numerous metal complexes are also used for photocatalytic reduction of CO2. They are suitable for the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 because different metalloporphyrins exhibit strong absorption bands in the visible range, which are sensitive to the oxidation states of both metals and ligands [20,21,22]. Photocatalysis may lead to one-electron reduction of CO2 to oxalic acid or a two-electron reduction to produce CO and H2O which of course competes with the production of HCOOH. The function of a particular metal centre, the adjacent ligand or both affect selectivity for the production of CO or HCOOH. In this particular field, considerable research is also being done on the catalytic pathways for the multi-electron reduction of CO2 to methanol and methane. Therefore, there is enormous scope for designing first-row transition metals, viz., Fe, Mn or Ni based complexes with suitable ligands which can selectively reduce CO2 to desired products [23]. Scheme 1 depicts a schematic of the entire catalytic cycle for the hydrogenation of CO2 to formate. Now, the ability of the metal-hydride to transform hydrides into CO2 is the key factor in this reactions. Two factors that affect this capability are the kinetic barrier of hydride transfer (TS3,4 in Fig. 1 ) and thermodynamic hydricity ( Δ G H − 0 ) i.e. the change of standard Gibbs free energy for breaking the M-H bond (in Eq. (1)) [24,25]. Hydricity of formate is the free energy change for the loss of a hydride ion from formate anion to produce gaseous CO2, and it is estimated to be 24.1 kcal/mol in H2O [26,27,28]. The ability to convert a hydride to CO2 is obviously only possible for metal-hydrides that are more hydridic than formate (having < 24.1 kcal/mol in water), otherwise the opposite reaction would take place. However, there are few reports of transition-metal hydrides with their suitable hydricities in water [29,30,31,32,33,34]. Ni hydrides have received positive attention in this regard [29,35,36,37]. Yang et al. has demonstrated that catalytic hydrogenation by NiP4 complex is more advantageous in water when compared to other solvents like acetonitrile or DMSO [38]. As a result, the catalytic hydricity has proved successful, however there is still question over the exact details of the mechanism. Theoretical modelling, addressing the details of the experimental findings is scattered in the literature. A theoretical understanding of the geometry and electrical structure of free Ni(II) complexes and their hydrides is required to develop this area [39,40]. The main motivation for the current research is to correlate the hydride transfer barrier to the geometries, spin states, and overall electronic structures of the Ni(II) complexes, their transition states and intermediates. We first computationally study experimentally realized Ni-bis(diphosphine) complex (NiP4) as a reference standard and then model a pyridine-containing ligand (PNP), the hydride transfer barrier of which is significantly lower than that of the NiP4 complex. We try to model the complexes and the reaction scheme properly and investigate the mechanistic details using first-principles calculation. Our systematic study is expected to provide valuable guidelines for designing efficient catalyst which in one hand will save chemical hazard, on the other hand, the atomistic interpretation, obtained from theoretical analysis, will certainly provide intuitive ideas for improving the catalytic activities. 2 Computational details All the calculations are performed with the Gaussian 16 program package [41] using Becke's three-parameter exchange and the Lee–Yang–Parr correlation functional (B3LYP) [42]. The high reliability of this functional has been demonstrated by previous benchmark studies on various systems. The full electron 6–311G** basis set is used for non-metals (C, H, O, N and P) and LANL2DZ basis set with suitable core potential is used for Ni-metal [15,43]. The B3LYP functional has been successfully tested by many metal complexes and considered to be good enough for CO2 reduction reactions procedures [15,44,45]. Geometry optimizations of all the complexes, the reaction intermediates and the products were subjected to normal mode analysis to confirm the respective minimum (no imaginary frequency) or transition state (one imaginary frequency). All the reported energies of intermediate and transition states are Gibbs free energies in gas phase with entropy correction at 1 atm. pressure and 298.15 K. Solvation effect was consider by performing single point energy calculation using the SMD solvation model for different polar protic, polar aprotic and non-polar solvents. Intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) computations were used to confirm the transition-state structures connecting the right reactant and product sites. Non-covalent interaction (NCI) analysis of TS3,4 was carried out using the Multiwfn program [46], CPK and NCI isosurfaces were generated using the VMD 1.9.3 program [47]. Natural Bond Orbital (NBO) analyses were done using NBO 6.0 program suite as implemented in Gaussian 16 to see the effect of donor–acceptor type of stabilization energies among different NBOs (such as bonding (BD), antibonding (BD*) or lone-pair (LP) on the stability of the intermediate and TS of the complex. 3 Results and discussion First, we confirm that CO2 can be hydrogenated to produce HCOOH without the use of a catalyst. This uncatalyzed reaction is studied with computed value of free energy change ΔG is 13.43 kcal/mol (0.77 kcal/mol is the value of the corresponding electronic energy change, ΔE) in the gas phase, revealing the reaction's endergonicity. Fig. S1 illustrates how a potential energy profile is formed in the gas phase and how the reactants and the product are linked by a single TS with an imagined vibrational frequency of −2248.98 cm−1. The extremely high free energy barrier of 79.91 kcal/mol (73.43 kcal/mol is electronic energy barrier) denotes the difficulty of getting the reaction to proceed without a catalyst. To understand the mechanistic insight into CO2 hydrogenation catalysed by Ni-PNP complex, the possible pathways are presented in Scheme 1. In the catalytic cycle, there are four consecutive processes i.e. formation of active catalyst, oxidative addition of dihydrogen, metal hydride formation through deprotonation and hydride donation to CO2 [48]. The most important phase is the transfer of hydrides, which includes two major factors one is kinetic energy barrier and another is thermodynamic hydricity i.e. bond breaking free energy change for metal hydride (M-H) bond [49]. Compared to the corresponding cobalt phosphines, rhodium and iridium-based phosphine catalysts are superior hydride donors because their hydricities are much lower than the 44 kcal/mol needed for the direct hydride transfer to CO2 [27,26]. For improving the hydride donating ability of the mono hydride complex, we design pyridine based NiL4 type of complex. We believe that the pyridine-based catalyst with a PNP ligand could be a very promising catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation reaction as the two most important steps i.e. homolytic H2 cleavage and metal hydride bond formation steps are favourable for these ligand system [50]. Both tetrahedral and square planar geometries are observed for NiL4 type of complexes, depending on the orientation of the multidentate ligand and the field strength of the ligand [49]. Previous studies showed that the NiP4 type of complexes with bidentate diphosphine ligands are of square planar geometry which is always preferred with singlet spin multiplicity [14]. In the present study we design Ni-PNP type of complex which has four possible structures i.e. square planar and tetrahedral structures with both singlet and triplet spin states. Among the four structures, tetrahedral triplet spin multiplicity has the lowest energy (which is shown in Fig. 2 ). In the second stage i.e. oxidative addition of hydrogen to form octahedral complex, it is preferred by singlet spin multiplicity. Due to more π-acidic character of the PNP ligand, H2 binds with the Ni-PNP complex with a more σ-donating fashion [49]. The metal-H2 complex formation energy is calculated to be endergonic for Ni-PNP-H2. In the energy profile diagram using M06L functional the calculated activation energy for this process is 49.84 kcal/mol in gas phase and 45.55 kcal/mol in water (Fig. 1). In the B3LYP functional the energy is 60.66 kcal/mol (Fig. S2). In the third stage i.e. deprotonation, one M-H bond in octahedral complex is completely broken to form a metal hydride complex. This may occur directly or via the assistance of an external base (e.g. tertiary amine) as depicted in Scheme 1. The structure of the metal-hydride turns into distorted square-pyramidal with almost equal energy in both the spin states indicating that the singlet and triplet states are in equilibrium. Optimized geometries of the metal hydride could be found in Fig. S3 for both spin states. It is observed that the triplet hydride has longer M-H bond (1.608 Å in B3LYP/6–311G** level and 1.645 Å in M06L/6–311G** level of theory, which indicates easier donation of hydride from the triplet state. From the energy profile diagram, it is seen that formation of five coordinated metal hydride complex through the deprotonation step is 203 kcal/mol (using M06L) energy more stable than the corresponding six-membered M-H2 complex. Using B3LYP calculation this energy gap is 213 kcal/mol. Noteworthy, such a high formation energy of metal hydride can easily compensate the endergonic formation of metal-H2 complex. In the fourth stage i.e. hydride transfer process, the linear CO2 molecule takes on a bent shape as schematically shown in Scheme 1. In this process, hydride transfer mechanism from metal complex to CO2 is an important step. The activated CO2 assists in the cleavage of M-H sigma bond to reach an intermediate state 4 through a single transition state TS3,4. There are two possible routes for the hydride transfer mechanism: (i) direct, and (ii) indirect [17]. In the case of a direct mechanism, CO2 interacts directly with the H of the metal-hydride due to its electrophilic character. But in the indirect case, CO2 first binds to the vacant site of metal complex then a process for transferring hydrides occurs. In our complex, there are no vacant sites accessible. So, the reaction occurs via the direct hydride transfer mechanism. The energy barrier for the direct hydride transfer (3→4) to the carbon atom of the CO2 is calculated to be 10.10 kcal/mol in gas phase and 4.54 kcal/mol using water solvent in SMD model which is shown in the energy profile diagram (Fig. 1). Using B3LYP calculation the energy barrier is 10.30 kcal/mol (Fig. S2). Note that such energy barrier is much lower than that for previously reported iron complex which is 33.3 kcal/mol [51]. The TS3,4 structures are shown in Fig. 3 . The TS geometry indicates that the cleavage of M-H bond and the hydrogenation of CO2 are concurrently mobilized by the complex. A single imaginary frequency has a value of −326.89 cm−1 for singlet and −324.49 cm−1 for triplet. The Ni-H bond distance is increased to 1.622 Å (B3LYP), 1.686 Å (M06L) for triplet at TS3,4 from its equilibrium bond distance of 1.608 Å (B3LYP), 1.645 Å (M06L) and in CO2 the ∠OCO angle becomes 152.58° (B3LYP), 153.82° (M06 L) for triplet at TS3,4. As the M–H bond distance increases, the activation barrier decreases. The optimized structures of intermediate 4 and 4′ are shown in Fig. S3. Non-covalent interaction (NCI) analysis (which consider neighbouring van der Waals and other weak interections) of TS3,4 was carried out using the Multiwfn program, CPK and NCI isosurfaces were generated using the VMD 1.9.3 program. Here we see the strong repulsion through the bulky phosphine ligand which is indicated by the red colour. Blue colour indicates strong attraction between Ni metal and ligand PNP ligand. Green colour indicates van der Waals interaction. For Ni-PNP complex, NBO analysis reveals that the donor acceptor interactions involving Ni-H σ-bond pair and vacant d-orbital of Ni are primarily responsible for stabilising the complex (Fig. 4 ). More the M-H bond tends to dissociate, less would be barrier height for the metal hydride transfer process. Table 1 contains the computed TS3,4 barrier height. Table 1 clearly shows that utilizing B3LYP/6–311G** levels of computation, the estimated barrier height for NiP4 complexes with R= −CH3 is in the order of 25.44 kcal/mol; the M06L functional estimating the lower barrier height of 23.24 kcal/mol [14]. Surprisingly, the suggested complex containing the PNP ligand has a barrier height that is substantially lower, 10.30 and 10.10 kcal/mol only within B3LYP/6–311G** and M06L/6–311G** level of theory, respectively. Rawat et.al. reported the activation barriers for this step (TS3,4) are 5.1 to 19.4 kcal/mol for Mn complex with different ligand which are shown in Table S1 [15]. Similarly, Xinzheng Yang investigated the process of hydride transfer across many Fe-complexes and predicted the barriers ranging from 16.6 to 19.5 kcal/mol [52]. It is noticeable that our estimated free energy barriers for the hydride transfer barrier are much lower than those found in previous reports. Furthermore, as depicted in Table 2 , it is seen that the energy barrier of TS1,2 decreases with increasing polarity of the solvent. The energy gap is maximum in gas phase (i.e. no solvent) and minimum in polar protic solvent that means the TS1,2 structure is more stabilised in polar protic solvent. But it is seen that the polarity effect is reverse in the TS2′,3 structure with respect to TS1,2 that means with increasing the polarity of the solvent the energy barrier for the TS2′,3 structure is increasing (Table 2). From the above result it is concluded that with increasing the polarity of the solvent, the intermediate 2 gets more stabilised than the transition state TS2′,3. As a result, the energy barrier for this process is follows polar protic solvent > polar aprotic solvent > non polar solvent > gas phase. From the Table 2 it is also revealed that the energy of TS3,4 transition state is more stabilised in polar protic solvent than the non-polar solvent and consequently the energy barrier height for this step follows polar protic solvent < polar aprotic ≈ non-polar solvent < gas phase. This lower energy barrier indicates that the hydride transfer is relatively faster in polar protic solvent. As an overall conclusion, it is recommended that the polar protic solvent is more suitable for this reaction. The hydride transfer barrier of the corresponding hydrogenation reaction may be related to the geometry and electrical structure of the metal-hydride intermediate 3 [53]. Table 3 clearly shows that when the ligand is changed from P4 to PNP, the hydride transfer barrier progressively lowers as the metal-H bond length of intermediate 3 increases. The length of the metal hydride bonds plays a significant role in the hydrogenation process. The transition state structures (TS3,4) of the complexes have M-H bonds with lengths of 1.622 Å (B3LYP) and 1.686 Å (M06L). These M-H bond distances show that as the bond distance rises, the activation barrier for hydride transfer decreases. The formal residual charges over the hydride ions provide additional support for the findings. According to Table 3, the Ni-PNP complex has a much more negative NBO charge(e) over the hydride ion (NBOH) compared to the NiP4 complexes which have NBOH charges of 0.063 using the same level of theory, indicating a much higher probability of hydride donation. In order to gain further understanding, we calculate the structural strain energy ( Δ E s t r a i n t o t a l ) when CO2 is hydrogenated by metal hydride 3 to reach the TS point (TS3,4). As a result, two energy variables are involved in this process due to the distortion of the intermediate 3 ( Δ E s t r a i n c o m p l e x ) and the distortion of linear O = C = O to a bent structure similar to that in the TS3,4 ( Δ E s t r a i n C O 2 ). As shown in Fig 5 , with the example of the Ni-PNP complex, these energies are come from the overall energy differences between the TS3,4 fragments and their initial reactant counterparts. As indicated in Table 4 , the values are significantly less than those of the CO2 angle strain ( Δ E s t r a i n C O 2 ). However, the Ni-PNP complex has the lowest calculated strain energy, which also follows the same pattern as the hydride transfer barrier. In the case of the Ni-PNP complex, decreased strain energy suggests that less structural deformation is needed during hydride transfer. Thus, we show that the Ni-PNP complex is the better hydride donor, at least in terms of kinetics. After the intermediate 4 releases one unit of formate, the catalyst is subsequently regenerated in accordance with the reaction scheme shown in Scheme 1. It should be noted that the intermediate 4 is isomerized to produce the more stable intermediate 4′, which leads to the formation of a metal-O bond. The intermediate 4′ can be thought of as the catalyst's resting state, which naturally impacts the probability of the opposing reaction (dehydrogenation), which will be covered later. Now, in order to determine whether such hydride transfer mechanisms are thermodynamically feasible, one must compute the standard Gibbs free energy change ( Δ G H − 0 ) [54][27] of the reaction (1) [MLH] n + → [ML]( n +1)+ + H − which is also referred to as simple hydricity or thermodynamic hydricity. For the possibility of forward reaction or the capacity for hydride transfer will increase with increasing negative Δ G H 0 . It is important to note that the incorrect estimation of Δ G H − 0 led to a long-range error in the direct hydricity calculations [55]. The Δ G H − 0 of a metal hydride ([MLH] n +) can also be calculated using a reference "isodesmic reaction," such as the hydricity of formate, for which the experimental value is known [55]. Therefore, without having to determine the value of Δ G H − 0 the hydricity of [MLH] n + can be determined from the standard free energy change (∆G0) of the overall hydride transfer reaction, as indicated in Eq. (4). (2) [MLH] n +→[ML]( n +1)+ + H − (3) CO2 + H −→HCOO− (4) [MLH] n + + CO2→[ML]( n +1)+ + HCOO− Although correct determination of Δ G H − 0 is challenging in the solution phase, particularly in water [29], it does not usually impact the overall qualitative trend [25]. Additionally, consideration of explicit solvents was demonstrated. Here, the standard hydricity of formate, which is assumed to be 24.1 kcal/mol in water [29], is used to derive the hydricity values. All values are given in Table 3. Recall that the possibility of CO2 hydrogenation or dehydrogenation of formate or formic acid depends on the hydricity of the metal hydride [56,52,4]. Remember that compared to NiP4 complexes, Ni-PNP complex has a far lower hydride transfer barrier. We also calculate the energy barrier of the reverse route, or the energy difference between 4′ and TS3,4, to determine whether the dehydrogenation process is feasible. The computed barrier heights (4→TS3,4) for NiP4 (R= -CH3) and Ni-PNP complexes are 17.08 and 14.02 kcal/mol, respectively. It can be shown that the hydrogenation process of Ni-PNP complex is significantly simpler than the dehydrogenation procedure. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we investigate the mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation catalysed by Ni(II) complexes with pyridine based ligands. The complex reaction mechanisms designed to illustrate that pyridine based Ni-complex can be superior catalysts for the CO2 hydrogenation process and the reaction thermodynamics are very much comparable with the earlier theoretical investigation. For the entire catalytic cycle, the two most crucial reaction stages are identified as follows: First, homolytic H2 cleavage, then a mechanism for transferring hydrides. The impact of PNP-based ligands on the homolytic H2 cleavage and the hydride transfer processes are still to be determined. Our findings show that the addition of pyridine-based ligand significantly accelerates the homolytic H2 cleavage step, and that Ni-PNP complex catalysed reactions have the lower activation barriers. In-depth analyses have been performed on the complexes' geometry, spin states, included intermediates, and transition states. It has been demonstrated that NiP4 complexes favour square planar shapes with singlet spin multiplicity, while Ni-PNP type tetradentate ligands produce a tetrahedral complex with Ni(II) that possesses a triplet ground state. We calculate the energy barrier for the hydride transfer mechanism, which is considered to be the most significant step in this kind of hydrogenating and dehydrogenating reaction. We also correlate hydride transfer barrier with the structure of ligand, CO2 bond strain, complex strain, the residual charge on the reactive sites, and finally the hydricity of the metal hydride intermediate. The computed energy barrier for Ni-PNP complex is 10 kcal/mol only. Finally, we also discuss the opposing process of hydrogenation versus dehydrogenation by those complexes. Thus, we predict that our findings can be very instrumental for designing pyridine based Ni(II) catalyst for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. coredata.dc:description: Recent developments, industrialization, and modernization lead to production of more and more pollutants (such as CO2: ∼ 417.06 ppm) and such rapid growth of CO2 level results in global warming and the greenhouse effect. So, it is essential to conduct research on converting CO2 into fuels using carbon-neutral energy. Recent research on molecular catalysts has improved the rates of converting CO2 to formate. However, these catalysts require extremely high temperatures and pressures and are made of expensive metals like iridium, ruthenium, and rhodium. Herein, DFT-based computational studies have been performed on the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 by different Ni(II) complexes in ambient conditions. Using state-of-the-art calculations, we demonstrate how the geometry and spin states of Ni(II) complexes containing different types of ligands affect their catalytic role in CO2 hydrogenation. It has been reported that hydride transfer is the most crucial step for such kind of hydrogenation reaction. We start with previously synthesised Ni-bis(diphosphine) complexes of type NiP4 and by extrapolating the concept, we propose a novel kind of Ni-PNP complex with a significantly lower hydride transfer barrier. We also calculate the hydricities of the nickel hydride complexes in order to correlate these thermodynamic parameters with the kinetic barrier of hydride transfer.
coredata.dc:title: Designing Nickel-based catalysts for the hydrogenation of CO2 under Ambient conditions: A computational study
